title: Cervarix Vaccine (PF) Intramuscular: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for Cervarix Vaccine (PF) intramuscular on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) is a [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) used to prevent [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/health-check-cancer-risk/default.htm) of the [cervix](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-cervix). It is also used to prevent abnormal tissue growth in the cervix that can lead to cancer. These conditions are commonly caused by certain types of [human papillomavirus](https://www.webmd.com/sexual-conditions/hpv-genital-warts/hpv-virus-information-about-human-papillomavirus) ( [HPV](https://www.webmd.com/sexual-conditions/hpv-genital-warts/hpv-virus-information-about-human-papillomavirus)). [Vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) work by ( [immunity](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/10-immune-system-busters-boosters)) against the virus.This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) does not protect against all [types of HPV](https://www.webmd.com/sexual-conditions/hpv-genital-warts/hpv-symptoms-tests), only the types in the vaccine. It is used to prevent the diseases and will not treat active [cervical cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/cervical-cancer/what-is-cervical-cancer) or other diseases caused by the types of HPV in the vaccine. How to use Cervarix Vaccine (PF) 20 Mcg-20 Mcg/0.5 Ml Intramuscular Suspension Read all [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) information available from your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional before receiving the [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide). If you have any questions, ask your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional. This vaccine is given by injection into the muscle of the upper arm by a health care professional. This vaccine is given as 3 separate doses. The second dose should be given 1 month after the first dose, and the third dose should be given 6 months after the first dose. Follow the vaccination schedule closely for the vaccine to be most effective. To help you remember, mark your calendar to keep track of when to receive your next dose. Side Effects Redness, swelling, and pain at the injection site may occur. If any of these effects last or get worse, tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional promptly. Rarely, some people have symptoms such as [fainting](https://www.webmd.com/brain/understanding-fainting-basics), [dizziness](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/understanding-dizziness-basics), [vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/vision-basics) changes, or [ringing in the ears](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/understanding-tinnitus-basics) just after getting a [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) injection. [Seizure](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics)-like movements may also rarely happen after injection with this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide). Tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional right away if you have any of these symptoms. Sitting or lying down may help, since these symptoms usually don't last long. Remember that this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) has been prescribed because your health care professional has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [rash](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/common-rashes), dizziness, [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your health care professional. Contact the health care professional for medical advice about side effects. The following numbers do not provide medical advice, but in the US you may report side effects to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967. In Canada, you may call the Vaccine Safety Section at Public Health Agency of Canada at 1-866-844-0018. Precautions Before receiving this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation), tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional if you are allergic to it; or to other [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation); or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients (such as latex found in the packaging of some products), which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional for more details. Before receiving this vaccination, tell your health care professional your medical history, especially of: [immune system disorders](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/autoimmune-diseases) (such as due to [HIV](https://www.webmd.com/hiv-aids/understanding-aids-hiv-basics) infection, certain cancers such as [leukemia](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/understanding-leukemia-basics)/ [lymphoma](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/lymphoma-cancer), [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/health-check-cancer-risk/default.htm) or [radiation](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/what-to-expect-from-radiation-therapy) treatment), current fever/illness. This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) is not recommended for use during pregnancy. Consult your health care professional for more details. It is unknown if this vaccine passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. Consult your health care professional before breast-feeding. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional. Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Some products that may interact with this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) include: drugs that As with any [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation), this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) may not fully protect everyone who receives it. Getting this vaccine does not replace [cervical cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/cervical-cancer/what-is-cervical-cancer) screening. Continue to have regular [obstetrician](https://www.webmd.com/women/guide/what-to-expect-from-an-ob-gyn-visit)/ [gynecologist](https://www.webmd.com/women/guide/what-to-expect-from-an-ob-gyn-visit) checkups. Keep vaccine records for yourself and all of your children, and after your children are grown provide their records to them and their [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professionals. This will prevent unnecessary re- [vaccinations](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation). If you miss a dose in the vaccination schedule, contact your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional right away. Store in the refrigerator. Do not freeze. Protect from light. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company.
